    • colorText

      public void colorText(String color, int startPosRow, int startPosCol, int endPosRow, int endPosCol)
      This function colors a specified range of text in a display buffer with the given color.
      Parameters:
      color - The `color` parameter in the `colorText` method represents the color that you want to apply to the text within the specified range. This color can be specified using color codes or color names depending on the context in which you are working. For example, you can use color names like "RED
      startPosRow - The `startPosRow` parameter represents the starting row index where you want to begin coloring the text in the display buffer. If the provided `startPosRow` is less than 0, the method sets it to 1 before proceeding with coloring the text.
      startPosCol - The `startPosCol` parameter in the `colorText` method represents the starting column position where the color should be applied within the specified row.
      endPosRow - The `endPosRow` parameter represents the ending row position for the text color change in the `colorText` method. It specifies the row number where the color change operation should stop.
      endPosCol - The `endPosCol` parameter in the `colorText` method represents the ending column position where the color should be applied in the text. The method will apply the specified color to the text starting from the `startPosCol` up to (but not including) the `endPosCol`

    • formatText

      public void formatText(String format, int startPosRow, int startPosCol, int endPosRow, int endPosCol)
      The formatText function in Java applies formatting to a specified range of text within a display buffer based on the given format parameter.
      Parameters:
      format - The `format` parameter specifies the type of formatting to be applied to the text. It can be one of the following values: "bold", "faint", "italic", or "underline". If the format is not one of these values, the default formatting will be applied.
      startPosRow - The `startPosRow` parameter in the `formatText` method represents the starting row index where the text formatting will begin. If the `startPosRow` value is less than 0, it is set to 1 to ensure it starts from the first row.
      startPosCol - The `startPosCol` parameter in the `formatText` method represents the starting column position where the text formatting should begin within a specific row of text.
      endPosRow - The `endPosRow` parameter in the `formatText` method represents the ending row position where the text formatting will be applied. This method formats text within a specified range of rows and columns in a display buffer. The formatting specified by the `format` parameter (e.g., "bold",
      endPosCol - The `endPosCol` parameter in the `formatText` method represents the ending column position within the text where the formatting should be applied. This parameter specifies the column index where the formatting should end for each row of text within the specified range.

    • displayText

      public void displayText(String text, int startPosRow, int startPosCol, int maxLength)
      The `displayText` function displays text on a display buffer with specified starting position and maximum length per line.
      Parameters:
      text - The `text` parameter is the string that you want to display on the screen. It contains the content that you want to show in the display area.
      startPosRow - The `startPosRow` parameter in the `displayText` method represents the starting row position where the text will be displayed on the screen or display buffer. It indicates the row number where the text will begin to be displayed.
      startPosCol - The `startPosCol` parameter in the `displayText` method represents the starting column position where the text should be displayed on the screen or display buffer. It indicates the column index where the text should begin to be shown.
      maxLength - The `maxLength` parameter in the `displayText` method specifies the maximum number of characters that can be displayed on a single line. If the input text exceeds this length, it will be split into multiple lines with each line containing up to `maxLength` characters.

    • displayCursor

      public void displayCursor(int screen, int index)
      The `displayCursor` function updates the cursor position on the screen and displays the cursor character at that position.
      Parameters:
      screen - The `screen` parameter in the `displayCursor` method represents the screen number where the cursor should be displayed. It is used to determine the specific cursor position based on the screen.
      index - The `index` parameter in the `displayCursor` method represents the index of the cursor position within the `CursorPosition` array for a specific screen. It is used to determine the row and column coordinates of the cursor position on the screen.

    • loadScreen

      public void loadScreen(int screenIndex)
      The `loadScreen` function initializes a new display buffer with the content of a specified screen index and resets cursor positions.
      Parameters:
      screenIndex - The `screenIndex` parameter in the `loadScreen` method is an integer value that represents the index of the screen to be loaded from the `screens` array.

    • fillChar

      public void fillChar(int startPosRow, int startPosCol, int endPosRow, int endPosCol, char c)
      This Java function fills a rectangular area in a display buffer with a specified character.
      Parameters:
      startPosRow - The `startPosRow` parameter represents the starting row index where the character `c` will be filled in the display buffer.
      startPosCol - The `startPosCol` parameter represents the starting column index where you want to begin filling the character `c` in the display buffer.
      endPosRow - End position row is the row index where you want to stop filling the character 'c' in the display buffer.
      endPosCol - End position column index
      c - The parameter `c` in the `fillChar` method represents the character that will be used to fill the specified range of positions in the display buffer. This character will be set at each position within the specified row and column range.

    • displayCard

      public void displayCard(int posRow, int posCol, String name, int health, int power, int cost, int costType, ArrayList<String> abilities)
      The `displayCard` function is used to display a card with specified attributes at a given position on the display buffer.
      Parameters:
      posRow - The `posRow` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the position of the row where the card will be displayed on the screen. It is an integer value that determines the vertical placement of the card within the display area.
      posCol - The `posCol` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the column position where the card will be displayed within the display buffer. It is used to determine where the card's visual representation will start horizontally on the screen.
      name - The `name` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the name of the card that will be displayed. It is a String value that contains the name of the card.
      health - The `health` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the health points of a card in a card game. It indicates how much damage the card can take before being defeated or removed from play. The `health` value is typically reduced when the card is attacked or takes damage from other cards
      power - The `power` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the attack power of the card. It indicates how much damage the card can deal to other cards or players in the game.
      cost - The `cost` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the cost of playing the card in a card game. It indicates the amount of resources or currency required to play the card. The cost is typically deducted from a player's available resources when the card is played. In the context of the
      abilities - The `displayCard` method you provided is used to display a card with specific attributes at a given position on the screen. The `abilities` parameter in this method is an `ArrayList` that contains the abilities of the card.

    • displayCard

      public void displayCard(int posRow, int posCol, Card card)
      The `displayCard` method in Java takes a position, card object, and displays its attributes.
      Parameters:
      posRow - The `posRow` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the position of the card in the row where it will be displayed. It is used to determine the row in which the card will be displayed on the screen or user interface.
      posCol - The `posCol` parameter in the `displayCard` method represents the position column where the card will be displayed. It is used to determine the horizontal placement of the card on the display or game board.
      card - The `card` parameter in the `displayCard` method is an object of the `Card` class. It contains information about a specific card, such as its name, health, power, cost, and abilities.

    • displayCardBig

      public void displayCardBig(Card card)
      The `displayCardBig` function in Java displays information about a card, including its name, cost, health, and power, in a visually appealing format.
      Parameters:
      card - The `displayCardBig` method takes a `Card` object as a parameter. This method is responsible for displaying a larger version of the card on the screen, including the card's name, cost, health, and power.
